title: Rotational KE - is disk KE zero or not zero

content.question: A solid, uniform disk is spinning about an axis through its center while its center of mass remains at rest. Which of the following correctly describes the disk’s kinetic energy <math alttext="K" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>K</mi></math>, and provides supporting reasoning?

choices.label: <math alttext="K" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>K</mi></math> is zero. The velocity of the disk’s center of mass is zero.

<math alttext="K" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>K</mi></math> is zero. For every point on the disk moving with a translational velocity <math alttext="vector v" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mover accent="true"><mi>v</mi><mo>→</mo></mover></math>, there is another point on the disk moving with the opposite velocity <math alttext="negative vector v" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>−</mo><mover accent="true"><mi>v</mi><mo>→</mo></mover></mpadded></math>.
<math alttext="K" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>K</mi></math> is greater than zero. The disk’s mass and rotational inertia are both greater than zero.
<math alttext="K" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>K</mi></math> is greater than zero. Except for the disk’s center, all parts of the disk are moving.

content.answer: <math alttext="K" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>K</mi></math> is greater than zero. Except for the disk’s center, all parts of the disk are moving.
